sn16.6:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.

sn16.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn16.6:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn16.6:1.5.pli: Ahaṃ vā, kassapa, bhikkhū ovadeyyaṃ tvaṃ vā;
sn16.6:1.5.eng: Either you or I should advise the mendicants

sn16.6:1.6.pli: ahaṃ vā bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyyaṃ tvaṃ vā”ti.
sn16.6:1.6.eng: and give them a Dhamma talk.”

sn16.6:2.1.pli: “Dubbacā kho, bhante, etarahi bhikkhū, dovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgatā, akkhamā, appadakkhiṇaggāhino anusāsaniṃ.
sn16.6:2.1.eng: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
sn16.6:2.1.comm: A list of such qualities is given at MN 15:3.1.

sn16.6:2.2.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhante, addasaṃ bhaṇḍañca nāma bhikkhuṃ ānandassa saddhivihāriṃ abhijikañca nāma bhikkhuṃ anuruddhassa saddhivihāriṃ aññamaññaṃ sutena accāvadante:
sn16.6:2.2.eng: Take the monk named Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s protégé. He’s been competing in studies with the monk named Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s protégé. They say:
sn16.6:2.2.comm: Bhaṇḍa and Abhiñjika are mentioned only here.

sn16.6:2.3.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’”ti.
sn16.6:2.3.eng: ‘Come on, monk, who can speak more? Who can speak better? Who can speak longer?’”

sn16.6:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn16.6:3.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

sn16.6:3.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena bhaṇḍañca bhikkhuṃ ānandassa saddhivihāriṃ abhijikañca bhikkhuṃ anuruddhassa saddhivihāriṃ āmantehi:
sn16.6:3.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s protégé, and the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s protégé that

sn16.6:3.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn16.6:3.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks and said,

sn16.6:4.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
sn16.6:4.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

sn16.6:4.2.pli: “saccaṃ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, aññamaññaṃ sutena accāvadatha:
sn16.6:4.2.eng: “Is it really true, monks, that you’ve been competing in studies, saying:

sn16.6:4.3.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’”ti?
sn16.6:4.3.eng: ‘Come on, monk, who can speak more? Who can speak better? Who can speak longer?’”

sn16.6:4.5.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha:
sn16.6:4.5.eng: “Have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this:

sn16.6:4.7.pli: ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’”ti?
sn16.6:4.7.eng: see who can recite more and better and longer’?”

sn16.6:4.9.pli: “No ce kira me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha, atha kiñcarahi tumhe, moghapurisā, kiṃ jānantā kiṃ passantā evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā aññamaññaṃ sutena accāvadatha:
sn16.6:4.9.eng: “If you’ve never known me to teach the Dhamma like this, what then do you know and see, you futile men, that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training you’d compete in studies to

sn16.6:4.10.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’”ti.
sn16.6:4.10.eng: see who can speak more and better and longer?”

sn16.6:5.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn16.6:5.1.eng: Then those monks bowed with their heads at the Buddha’s feet and said,

sn16.6:5.2.pli: “accayo no, bhante, accagamā, yathābāle yathāmūḷhe yathāakusale, ye mayaṃ evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā aññamaññaṃ sutena accāvadimha:
sn16.6:5.2.eng: “We made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of us in that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we competed in studies to

sn16.6:5.3.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’ti.
sn16.6:5.3.eng: see who can speak more and better and longer.

sn16.6:5.4.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
sn16.6:5.4.eng: Please, sir, accept our mistake for what it is, so we will restrain ourselves in future.”

sn16.6:6.1.pli: “Taggha tumhe, bhikkhave, accayo accagamā yathābāle yathāmūḷhe yathāakusale, ye tumhe evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā aññamaññaṃ sutena accāvadittha:
sn16.6:6.1.eng: “Indeed, monks, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.

sn16.6:6.2.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko bahutaraṃ bhāsissati, ko sundarataraṃ bhāsissati, ko cirataraṃ bhāsissatī’ti.

sn16.6:6.3.pli: Yato ca kho tumhe, bhikkhave, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarotha, taṃ vo mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
sn16.6:6.3.eng: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

sn16.6:6.4.pli: Vuddhi hesā, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti āyatiñca saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti.
sn16.6:6.4.eng: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

sn16.7:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.

sn16.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn16.7:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

sn16.7:1.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

sn16.7:1.6.pli: Ahaṃ vā, kassapa, bhikkhū ovadeyyaṃ tvaṃ vā;
sn16.7:1.6.eng: Either you or I should advise the mendicants

sn16.7:1.7.pli: ahaṃ vā bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyyaṃ tvaṃ vā”ti.
sn16.7:1.7.eng: and give them a Dhamma talk.”

sn16.7:2.1.pli: “Dubbacā kho, bhante, etarahi bhikkhū, dovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgatā akkhamā appadakkhiṇaggāhino anusāsaniṃ.
sn16.7:2.1.eng: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.

sn16.7:2.2.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhante, saddhā natthi kusalesu dhammesu, hirī natthi kusalesu dhammesu, ottappaṃ natthi kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyaṃ natthi kusalesu dhammesu, paññā natthi kusalesu dhammesu, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.
sn16.7:2.2.eng: Sir, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.
sn16.7:2.2.comm: See similar teachings at AN 10.67 and AN 10.68.

sn16.7:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, kāḷapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāyateva vaṇṇena, hāyati maṇḍalena, hāyati ābhāya, hāyati ārohapariṇāhena.
sn16.7:3.1.eng: It’s like the moon in the waning fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, luminosity, and diameter and circumference only decline.

sn16.7:3.2.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, yassa kassaci saddhā natthi kusalesu dhammesu …pe…
sn16.7:3.2.eng: In the same way, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

sn16.7:3.6.pli: paññā natthi … kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.

sn16.7:4.1.eng: A faithless individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.2.eng: An individual with no conscience is in decline.

sn16.7:4.3.eng: An imprudent individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.4.eng: A lazy individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.5.eng: A witless individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.6.eng: An irritable individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.7.eng: An acrimonious individual is in decline.

sn16.7:4.8.eng: When there are no mendicant advisers there is decline.

sn16.7:5.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhante, saddhā atthi kusalesu dhammesu, hirī atthi kusalesu dhammesu, ottappaṃ atthi kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyaṃ atthi kusalesu dhammesu, paññā atthi kusalesu dhammesu, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.
sn16.7:5.1.eng: Sir, whoever has faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

sn16.7:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, juṇhapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vaḍḍhateva vaṇṇena, vaḍḍhati maṇḍalena, vaḍḍhati ābhāya, vaḍḍhati ārohapariṇāhena.
sn16.7:6.1.eng: It’s like the moon in the waxing fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, luminosity, and diameter and circumference only grow.

sn16.7:6.2.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, yassa kassaci saddhā atthi kusalesu dhammesu …
sn16.7:6.2.eng: In the same way, whoever has faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

sn16.7:6.6.pli: paññā atthi kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.

sn16.7:7.2.eng: An individual with a conscience doesn’t decline.

sn16.7:7.8.eng: When there are mendicant advisers there is no decline.”

sn16.7:8.2.pli: Yassa kassaci, kassapa, saddhā natthi kusalesu dhammesu …pe…
sn16.7:8.2.eng: Whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect decline, not growth …

sn16.7:8.6.pli: paññā natthi kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.

sn16.7:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, kassapa, kāḷapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāyateva vaṇṇena …pe…

sn16.7:9.3.pli: Evameva kho, kassapa, yassa kassaci saddhā natthi kusalesu dhammesu …pe…

sn16.7:9.7.pli: paññā natthi kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no vuddhi.

sn16.7:9.15.eng: When there are no mendicant advisers there is decline.

sn16.7:10.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, kassapa, saddhā atthi kusalesu dhammesu …pe…
sn16.7:10.1.eng: Whoever has faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities can expect growth, not decline …

sn16.7:10.5.pli: paññā atthi kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.

sn16.7:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, kassapa, juṇhapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vaḍḍhateva vaṇṇena, vaḍḍhati maṇḍalena, vaḍḍhati ābhāya, vaḍḍhati ārohapariṇāhena.

sn16.7:11.2.pli: Evameva kho, kassapa, yassa kassaci saddhā atthi kusalesu dhammesu hirī atthi …

sn16.7:11.5.pli: paññā atthi kusalesu dhammesu tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihāni.

sn16.7:12.8.eng: When there are mendicant advisers there is no decline.”

sn16.8:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn16.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn16.8:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn16.8:1.5.pli: Ahaṃ vā, kassapa, bhikkhūnaṃ ovadeyyaṃ tvaṃ vā;
sn16.8:1.5.eng: Either you or I should advise the mendicants

sn16.8:1.6.pli: ahaṃ vā bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyyaṃ tvaṃ vā”ti.
sn16.8:1.6.eng: and give them a Dhamma talk.”

sn16.8:2.1.pli: “Dubbacā kho, bhante, etarahi bhikkhū, dovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgatā, akkhamā, appadakkhiṇaggāhino anusāsanin”ti.
sn16.8:2.1.eng: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.”

sn16.8:2.2.pli: “Tathā hi pana, kassapa, pubbe therā bhikkhū āraññikā ceva ahesuṃ āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādino, piṇḍapātikā ceva ahesuṃ piṇḍapātikattassa ca vaṇṇavādino, paṃsukūlikā ceva ahesuṃ paṃsukūlikattassa ca vaṇṇavādino, tecīvarikā ceva ahesuṃ tecīvarikattassa ca vaṇṇavādino, appicchā ceva ahesuṃ appicchatāya ca vaṇṇavādino, santuṭṭhā ceva ahesuṃ santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādino, pavivittā ceva ahesuṃ pavivekassa ca vaṇṇavādino, asaṃsaṭṭhā ceva ahesuṃ asaṃsaggassa ca vaṇṇavādino, āraddhavīriyā ceva ahesuṃ vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādino.
sn16.8:2.2.eng: “Kassapa, that’s because formerly the senior mendicants lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; and they praised these things. They were of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praised these things.

sn16.8:3.1.pli: Tatra yo hoti bhikkhu āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva piṇḍapātikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, paṃsukūliko ceva paṃsukūlikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, tecīvariko ceva tecīvarikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, appiccho ceva appicchatāya ca vaṇṇavādī, santuṭṭho ceva santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, pavivitto ceva pavivekassa ca vaṇṇavādī, asaṃsaṭṭho ceva asaṃsaggassa ca vaṇṇavādī, āraddhavīriyo ceva vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādī, taṃ therā bhikkhū āsanena nimantenti:
sn16.8:3.1.eng: The senior mendicants invite such a mendicant to a seat, saying:

sn16.8:3.2.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko nāmāyaṃ bhikkhu, bhaddako vatāyaṃ bhikkhu, sikkhākāmo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu; ehi, bhikkhu, idaṃ āsanaṃ nisīdāhī’ti.
sn16.8:3.2.eng: ‘Welcome, mendicant! What is this mendicant’s name? This mendicant is good-natured; he really wants to train. Please, mendicant, take a seat.’

sn16.8:4.1.pli: Tatra, kassapa, navānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ hoti:

sn16.8:4.2.pli: ‘yo kira so hoti bhikkhu āraññiko ceva āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, piṇḍapātiko ceva …pe… paṃsukūliko ceva … tecīvariko ceva … appiccho ceva … santuṭṭho ceva … pavivitto ceva … asaṃsaṭṭho ceva … āraddhavīriyo ceva vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādī, taṃ therā bhikkhū āsanena nimantenti—
sn16.8:4.2.eng: ‘It seems that when a mendicant lives in the wilderness … and is energetic, and praises these things, senior mendicants invite them to a seat …’

sn16.8:4.3.pli: ehi, bhikkhu, ko nāmāyaṃ bhikkhu, bhaddako vatāyaṃ bhikkhu, sikkhākāmo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu; ehi, bhikkhu, idaṃ āsanaṃ nisīdāhī’ti.

sn16.8:4.5.pli: tesaṃ taṃ hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
sn16.8:4.5.eng: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.

sn16.8:5.1.pli: Etarahi pana, kassapa, therā bhikkhū na ceva āraññikā na ca āraññikattassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva piṇḍapātikā na ca piṇḍapātikattassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva paṃsukūlikā na ca paṃsukūlikattassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva tecīvarikā na ca tecīvarikattassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva appicchā na ca appicchatāya vaṇṇavādino, na ceva santuṭṭhā na ca santuṭṭhiyā vaṇṇavādino, na ceva pavivittā na ca pavivekassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva asaṃsaṭṭhā na ca asaṃsaggassa vaṇṇavādino, na ceva āraddhavīriyā na ca vīriyārambhassa vaṇṇavādino.
sn16.8:5.1.eng: But these days, Kassapa, the senior mendicants don’t live in the wilderness … and aren’t energetic; and they don’t praise these things.

sn16.8:6.1.pli: Tatra yo hoti bhikkhu ñāto yasassī lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ taṃ therā bhikkhū āsanena nimantenti:
sn16.8:6.1.eng: When a mendicant is well-known and famous, a recipient of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, senior mendicants invite them to a seat:

sn16.8:6.2.pli: ‘ehi, bhikkhu, ko nāmāyaṃ bhikkhu, bhaddako vatāyaṃ bhikkhu, sabrahmacārikāmo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu; ehi, bhikkhu, idaṃ āsanaṃ nisīdāhī’ti.
sn16.8:6.2.eng: ‘Welcome, mendicant! What is this mendicant’s name? This mendicant is good-natured; he’s fond of his fellow monks. Please, mendicant, take a seat.’

sn16.8:7.1.pli: Tatra, kassapa, navānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ hoti:

sn16.8:7.2.pli: ‘yo kira so hoti bhikkhu ñāto yasassī lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ taṃ therā bhikkhū āsanena nimantenti—
sn16.8:7.2.eng: ‘It seems that when a mendicant is well-known and famous, a recipient of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, senior mendicants invite them to a seat …’

sn16.8:7.3.pli: ehi, bhikkhu, ko nāmāyaṃ bhikkhu, bhaddako vatāyaṃ bhikkhu, sabrahmacārikāmo vatāyaṃ bhikkhu; ehi, bhikkhu, idaṃ āsanaṃ nisīdāhī’ti.

sn16.8:7.5.pli: Tesaṃ taṃ hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
sn16.8:7.5.eng: That is for their lasting harm and suffering.

sn16.8:7.6.pli: Yañhi taṃ, kassapa, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn16.8:7.6.eng: And if it could ever be rightly said that

sn16.8:7.7.pli: ‘upaddutā brahmacārī brahmacārūpaddavena abhipatthanā brahmacārī brahmacāriabhipatthanenā’ti, etarahi taṃ, kassapa, sammā vadamāno vadeyya: ‘upaddutā brahmacārī brahmacārūpaddavena abhipatthanā brahmacārī brahmacāriabhipatthanenā’”ti.
sn16.8:7.7.eng: spiritual practitioners have been imperiled by the peril of a spiritual practitioner, and vanquished by the vanquishing of a spiritual practitioner, it is these days that this could be rightly said.”
sn16.8:7.7.comm: The “peril of a spiritual practitioner” is one of three perils explained at MN 122:21.1. | Read abhibhavana, “overcoming, vanquishing”.

sn16.9:1.2.pli: “Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn16.9:1.3.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:2.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:2.1.eng: Whenever I want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, I enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn16.9:2.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:3.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharāmi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:3.1.eng: Whenever I want, with the fading away of rapture, I enter and remain in the third absorption, where I meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn16.9:3.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:4.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:4.1.eng: Whenever I want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

sn16.9:4.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:5.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:5.1.eng: Whenever I want, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

sn16.9:5.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:6.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:6.1.eng: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn16.9:6.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:7.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:7.1.eng: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, I enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

sn16.9:7.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati …pe… ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:8.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:8.1.eng: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, I enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

sn16.9:8.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati …pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.

sn16.9:9.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:9.1.eng: Whenever I want, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, I enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

sn16.9:10.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhomi—ekopi hutvā bahudhā homi, bahudhāpi hutvā eko homi; āvibhāvaṃ, tirobhāvaṃ, tirokuṭṭaṃ, tiropākāraṃ, tiropabbataṃ, asajjamāno gacchāmi, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karomi, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchāmi, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamāmi, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimasāmi parimajjāmi; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattemi.
sn16.9:10.1.eng: Whenever I want, I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. I control the body as far as the realm of divinity.

sn16.9:10.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.

sn16.9:11.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāmi, dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca.
sn16.9:11.1.eng: Whenever I want, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, I hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.

sn16.9:11.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati dibbāya sotadhātuyā …pe… dūre santike ca.

sn16.9:12.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
sn16.9:12.1.eng: Whenever I want, I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with my mind.

sn16.9:12.2.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāmi,
sn16.9:12.2.eng: I understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,

sn16.9:12.3.pli: vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ vītarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāmi,
sn16.9:12.3.eng: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’;

sn16.9:12.17.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajānāmi.

sn16.9:12.18.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti—

sn16.9:12.19.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti …pe…

sn16.9:12.20.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajānāti.

sn16.9:13.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
sn16.9:13.1.eng: Whenever I want, I recollect my many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

sn16.9:13.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.

sn16.9:14.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi: ‘ime vata, bhonto, sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā, ime vā pana, bhonto, sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā; te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi.
sn16.9:14.1.eng: Whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

sn16.9:14.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.

sn16.9:15.1.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.9:15.1.eng: I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.

sn16.9:15.2.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.

sn17.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn17.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn17.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn17.1:2.1.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko kaṭuko pharuso antarāyiko anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya.
sn17.1:2.1.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are grim, bitter, and harsh. They’re an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
sn17.1:2.1.comm: Dāruṇa is “grim”, fearful and unyielding as tough wood; kaṭuka is “bitter” like the taste, or like stabbing pain; pharusa is “harsh” like a prickly bush or abusive speech.

sn17.1:2.2.eng: So you should train like this:

sn17.1:2.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ pajahissāma, na ca no uppanno lābhasakkārasiloko cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatī’ti.
sn17.1:2.3.eng: ‘We will give up arisen possessions, honor, and popularity, and we won’t let them occupy our minds.’
